titleStmt.title:
The intended Speech of a famous Orator
agst ye Peace. 1711.

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: An orator Dismal of Nottinghamshire,
Who has forty years let out his conscience to hire,
Out of zeal for his Countrey & want of a place,
Is come up vi & armis to break ye Q──'s Peace.
He has vamp'd an old Speech; & ye Court to their sorrow
Shall hear him harangue against Prior to morrow.
When once he begins, he never will flinch,
But repeat ye same note a whole day like a Finch.
I have hear'd all ye Speech repeated by happy,
And mistakes to prevent have obtained a Copy.

The Speech.
Whereas notwthstanding I am in great pain
To hear we are making a peace wthout Spain:
But, most noble Senators, 'tis a great shame,
There should be a peace, whilest I'm Not-in-game.
The Duke shew'd me all his fine house; & ye Dutchess
From her Closet brought out a full purse in her clutches:
I talked of Peace, & they both gave a start,
His grace swore an Oath, & her Gr── let a f──t.
My long old·fashion'd pocket was presently cramm'd,
And sooner than vote for a peace, I'll be d──n'd.
But some will cry turncoat, & rip up old stories,
How I always pretended to be for ye Tories.
I answer, ye Tories were in my good graces,
Till all my Relations were put into places.
But still I'm in principle ever ye same,
And will quit my best friends, while I'm Not-in-game.
When I & some others subscribed our names
To a Plot for expelling my Master Kg James,
I withdrew my subscription by help of a blot;
And so might discover, or gain by ye Plot.
I had my advantage, I stood at defiance;
For Daniel was got from ye Den of ye Lions.
I came in wthout danger, & was I to blame?
For rather than hang, I would be Not-in-game.
I swore to ye Q──, yt ye P── of H────r
During her sacred life should never come over.
I made use of a Trope, yt an Heir to invite,
Was like keeping her Monumt always in sight:
But when I thought proper, I alter'd my note;
And in her own hearing I boldly did vote,
That her M────y stood in great need of a Tutor;
And must have an Old, or a Young Coadjutor.
For why! I would fain have put all in a flame,
Because for some reasons I was Not-in-game.
Now my new Benefactors have brought me about;
And I'll vote agst Peace wth Spain or without.
Tho' ye Court gives my Nephews, & Brothers, & Cosens,
And all my whole Family Places by dozens:
Yet since I know where a full purse may be found,
And hardly pay eighteen pence Tax in ye pound:
Since ye Tories have thus disappointed my hopes,
And will neither regard my figures nor tropes:
I'll Speach agst Peace while Dismal's my name;
And be a true Whigg while I'm Not-in-game.
